ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Broad understanding of critical theories (queer theory, indigenous studies, disability studies, critical race theory, trans studies). Policy development at federal levels and methods of implementation at district level. Less focus on state/local policy, but briefly covered.

I gained a much better sense of policy and theory in the context of ed studies, something I knew very little about previously! Also how to approach the question of how policy and theory can communicate with one another, which is very difficult and which previous theory courses I've taken have not tried to broach!
I learned more about how to write policy based on issues in education.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The small seminar environment is very intimate allowing for great conversation between students. Guests speakers were very knowledgeable and well-versed in the field, they made class more lively.

A big weakness of the course is that the different theories that are introduced are not quite explained fully, as well as how to incorporate theory into policy. Another weakness is that the weekly presentations are not engaging, and they do not provide a good explanation of the weekly readings. A strength is that the readings are very interesting, however, it would be nicer to dive deeper into them.
This class was amazing! The professor really makes sure to engage the class as much as he possibly can.

I felt the readings of the week sometimes would be more digestible if we had a preview of them from the week before. It would help to make connections with policy work better as well when reading about all the different theories.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Easily one of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale. Canfield is a great facilitator, so you get some fun discussions going, and it's a very ed-studies-safe-space vibe, which I think Yale in general could use a lot more of. You really get what you make of this class -- I recommend actually doing the readings every week, as they're very well-selected and engaging. You can genuinely leave this class with a shallow but broad understanding of different critical theories, or you can leave having really engaged with each, and gotten a lot out of it -- not just academically, but personally as well.
yes, nice education course and writing credit

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in theory as well as education issues in the country. Even though the theories are not explained well enough, it is still a good introduction.
Yes, Prog Craigfield was a wonderful instructor and I enjoyed going to each seminar each week. He made the classroom setting a safe space and fostered a productive learning environment.
